description.narrative: 1)Number of persons living with HIV/AIDS receiving antiretroviral treatment 2)Number of episodes of OIs treated among people ( adult) on ART (2012) 3)% of health facilities dispensing ARVs which have experienced a stock-out of at least one required ARV in the last 12 months 4)Number of HIV - positive pregnant women who received ARVs to reduce the risk of mother to child transmission 5)Number of Provinces supervised ( only 2013 and 2014) 6)Number of people trained in M&E and data collection tools ( only 2013 and 2014)

PIMS 4581 Angola National Biodiversity Project: Conservation of Iona National Park

title.narrative: Mid Term Evaluation Iona Project Angola Final

description.narrative: IONA CONSERVATION/ GEF
populated place

activity-description.narrative: The project will work on improving the infrastructure of Iona National Park, training its staff and developing studies about its flora, fauna and communities in order to rehabilitate the park.

description.narrative: independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Strengthen institutional capacity to manage the protected areas network in Angola

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration
Objective: Catalyze an improvement in the overall management of the protected areas network, through rehabilitating Iona National Park
1. Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

comment.narrative: at least 10%

Progress made towards the target. 5% Government has invested USD6M in Iona Park infrastructure, rehabilitated the training school at Quicama National Park, the entry gate, herbarium and conference room.

description.narrative: 2. Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

comment.narrative:
Systemic: 42%
Institutional: 39%
Individual: 35%

Systemic: 55%
Institutional: 50%
Individual: 45%

Progress made towards the target. Systemic 46% - establishment of CBD for policy and strategic oversight over PAs Institutional 40% - INBAC fully functional and responsible for implementation of PAs management support programmes in addition a training school was rehabilitated in Kuando Kubango for development of rangers and Park Administrators. Park Administrators participated at the World Parks Congress to share and learn lessons for improved capacities. Individual 37%- 20 park rangers and 17 staff were trained on security and use of GIS, 2 Managers trained on GEF procedures.

description.narrative: 3. Total government budget allocation (including operational, HR and capital budget) (US$ per annum) for protected area management

comment.narrative: US$1.5 million (as at 2010/11)
At least US$8 million
Target achieved and surpassed by far. Government has allocated $82M for PAs in 2015 budget. Giving the target level of $8M the result is over 100%.

description.narrative: 4. Number of protected areas in which the METT is adopted as a tool to monitor effectiveness of PA management

comment.narrative: At least 7
The methodology of METT has been adopted for all 7 PAs. However only Iona Park has started using the tool for data collection. Other parks are expected to come on stream in the near future.

description.narrative: Outcome 1) Rehabilitation of Iona National Park

5. Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool scorecard:
Iona National Park

comment.narrative: 5 points out of 102 possible, giving (Jan 2012) = 5%. [NOTE ON LOGFRAME 2014:]We need to make a correction to the baseline. In the PRODOC, it mentions a 7% rate. However, 5 points was the final baseline score, and all questions were considered (none considered n/a). This gives a total possible points of 102 and a percentage of 5% at the baseline.

Target achieved, but this needs to be independently vetted. Considerable improvement in the METT score has been attained since the original evaluation of November 20, 2011. The June 2015 METT evaluation returned a score of 32/102 = 31% in comparison with only 5/102 = 5% in 2011. In the 2011 assessment only three questions (1, 5 & 6) were awarded positive scores totaling 5 of a possible 9 points. The same total score for these three questions was also awarded in 2015. However, of the 39 questions that received zero scores in 2011, 23 received positive scores in the recent evaluation indicating a wide-ranging improvement in management effectiveness. The target of at least 45% in the final evaluation is considered attainable.

description.narrative: 6. Number of park management staff appointed, equipped, trained and deployed in the park

comment.narrative: Approaching target. Same as last year.

description.narrative: 7. Percentage (%) of park visitors obtaining a permit to traverse/overnight in the park

comment.narrative: At least 80%

Progress made towards the target. 40% of Park visitors is reported. Registration and entry fees collection pilot system launch in October 2014, has been reformulated and submitted to the local government authority for approval.

description.narrative: 8. Proportion (%) of the plains grassland habitats of the park (~600km2) overgrazed by livestock (goats and cattle)

comment.narrative: More than 35% (by 2011/12)
Less than 20%

Not possible to assess the indicator with accuracy, but there are good indications that the baseline may have been optimistic and the target even more so. The aerial survey is yet to be conducted. Observations from the ground indicate an increase of at least 40% of the grassland habitats of the park overgrazed by livestock.

description.narrative: 9. Increase in wildlife populations: Oryx Hartmann's Zebra Springbok Ostrich

comment.narrative:
9b) Oryx: 1650
9b) Hartmann's zebra: 265
9c) Springbok: 2400
9d) Ostrich: 400

9a) At least 2000
9b) At least 300
9c) At least 3500
9d) At least 500

Progress made towards the general target. Road count reports increase in wildlife populations as follows:
9b) Oryx: 1815 = 10% increase, but still below target
9b) Hartmann's zebra: 270 = 1% increase, meaning no change, given data uncertainty, meaning basically status quo vis-a-vis baseline
9c) Springbok: 3120 = 30% increase and approaching the target
9d) Ostrich: 420 = 5% increase, but still below target

description.narrative: 10. Number of critical natural freshwater springs and wells secured and accessible for use by medium-sized and large wildlife species

comment.narrative: Not possible to inform indicator. The hydrological study and the park management plan are in progress.

description.narrative: 11. Number of poaching incidents (park visitors) recorded in the park/annum

comment.narrative: No data
Less than 12

Target achieve. Less than 12. Shots were heard in Mupaca area located at east of Iona and further east towards Helola and Montenegro areas. Motorcycles are used to hunt wild animals within the Park in the south of Espinheira.

description.narrative: 12. Proportion (%) of communities living in the park that are adequately represented in the park management decision-making processes.

comment.narrative: More than 60%

No change. 0% of communities living in the park are represented the park management decision-making processes. Community study and park management planning initiated but are not yet at the stage of informing the project on this indicator.

description.narrative: 13. Number of job opportunities (direct and indirect) created for local communities living in, or adjacent to, the park

comment.narrative:
a) Direct: 0
b) Indirect: 0

a) Direct: at least 10
b) Indirect: at least 30
Target partially achieved. a) Direct: 12 members of community are community agents (rangers) b) Indirect: 0

description.narrative: 14. Average annual income (US$) of households living in the park

comment.narrative: US$155/annum
At least US$250/annum
Not possible to inform indicator at this stage. The study on Community Profile is on going and data on income levels will be ready at finalization of the exercise.

description.narrative: Outcome 2) Strengthen institutional capacity to manage the protected areas network
15. Strategic Plan, and a policy framework, for the system of protected areas formally approved by government

comment.narrative: No
Yes
Yes.

description.narrative: 16. Organizational structure for protected areas and job descriptions, remuneration levels and conditions of service for protected area staff formally adopted by government

comment.narrative: No
Yes
Not possible to inform indicator at this stage. The Park Management Plan study is on going which will frame the organizational structure of the Park.

description.narrative: 17. Recruitment of staff to approved protected area posts in the organogram of the protected area agency (as a % of posts with permanent staff appointed)

comment.narrative: At least 50%
Target fully achieved. Current level remains as reported in 2014.

description.narrative: 18. Number of protected area staff completing in-service training and skills development programmes

comment.narrative: Target fully achieved. Further to the basic trainings conducted last year, 17 government staff of INBAC and Park Administrators of Mavinga, Luengue-Luiana, Chimalavera and Cangandala, were trained in GIS.

description.narrative: 19. Number of senior protected area staff in a structured mentoring programme

comment.narrative: Target partially achieved. 1 senior staff, the Iona Park Administrator continue to be mentored by the International Park Manager.

description.narrative: 20. Number of national parks and strict nature reserves with fully documented up-to-date assessments of their state and biodiversity value

comment.narrative: Initiated.

description.narrative: 21. Number of protected areas where a structured rationalisation and rehabilitation programme is adequately resourced and under implementation

comment.narrative: 1. Currently, only the Iona Park rehabilitation programme is under implementation. Target partially Achieved.

description.narrative: Health - policy, planning and administration

1) Number of technician trained on M&E, data collection tools and stock management. 2) Number of GTNM&E meetings. 3) Number of health facility with SIS installed and operational. 4) Number of Provinces supervised regarding the use of thermometers, pharmacovigilance. 5) National formulary validated. (Note: The project started in 2015).

comment.narrative: 1) 338 technicians has been trained on M&E, data collection tools and stock management. 2) The national M&E group (GTNM&E) has been reactivated and TORs of the GTNM&E approved. 3) Software SIS installed at Province level. 4) Installation of thermometers in all the Provincials warehouse and health facilities. 5) List of essentials medicines validated and starting the elaboration of the National Formulary.
1) Support legal environment assessment to review legal barriers impeding access to services. 2) 5) National formulary of medicines validated. 3) transition project for the new global fund grant NFM
1) ToRs drafted, NGO selected evaluation will start next year 2) National formulary of essential medicines validated at tecnical level. 3) New Global Fund project signed.

description.narrative: 1) Number of technician trained on M&E, data collection tools and stock management. 2) Number of GTNM&E meetings. 3) Number of health facility with SIS installed and operational. 4) Number of Provinces supervised regarding the use of thermometers, pharmacovigilance. 5) National formulary validated. (Note: The project started in 2015).

comment.narrative: 1) 338 technicians has been trained on M&E, data collection tools and stock management. 2) The national M&E group (GTNM&E) has been reactivated and TORs of the GTNM&E approved. 3) Software SIS installed at Province level. 4) Installation of thermometers in all the Provincials warehouse and health facilities. 5) List of essentials medicines validated and starting the elaboration of the National Formulary.
1) Support legal environment assessment to review legal barriers impeding access to services. 2) 5) National formulary of medicines validated. 3) transition project for the new global fund grant NFM
1) ToRs drafted, NGO selected evaluation will start next year 2) National formulary of essential medicines validated at tecnical level. 3) New Global Fund project signed.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING THE NATIONAL RESPONSE TO HIV IN ANGOLA
